Award.AwardTitle: The Archaeology of Native American Expansion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Severin Fowles and his students at Barnard College will conduct the first archaeological investigations into the origins of Comanche regional influence during the early eighteenth century. Their research will focus on the Taos district of New Mexico, a strategic Comanche trading center and the first reported location of Comanche raiding in 1706. Recent discoveries of extensive Plains-style rock art and tipi encampments suggest that some of the earliest Comanche raiding base camps were located in the hidden confines of the Rio Grande gorge, a large rift valley just west of Taos. One site in particular - La Vista Verde Site - contains the remains of a large tipi encampment surrounded by hundreds of scratched rock art panels depicting warrior's paraphernalia, horse raids, and battle scenes. These are the first such archaeological remains found in New Mexico, and they require careful documentation to establish the chronology, ethnic identity, and underlying military logics of the sites' locations.
National Science Foundation funds will support three years of research designed to accomplish four goals: (1) additional archaeological survey within the Rio Grande gorge to expand the sample of Plains-style rock art and tipi sites, (2) detailed mapping of known tipi encampments, (3) documentation of Plains-style rock art panels, (4) creation of an online rock art database, and (5) consultations with the Comanches and other tribes to assist in the interpretation of the materials.

The rise of Comanche regional influence during the eighteenth century was a transformative event in the history of North America. Once in possession of the horse, the Comanches quickly migrated south out of Wyoming, conquered the South Plains, and assumed their position as a fully equestrian society with an unparalleled military that they used to dominate the vigorous new markets then emerging at the intersection of Spanish New Mexico, Spanish Texas, French Louisiana, and a variety of other Native American nations. For over a century, the Comanches dominated trade in horses, captives, guns, and bison across a tremendous region from the Great Plains deep into Mexico. Their military interventions were responsible for halting Spain's colonial aspirations in North America, ultimately paving the way for the United States' takeover of New Mexico and Texas. Moreover, the extensive trade in captives, orchestrated by the Comanches, transformed the ethnic configuration of Southwest communities, resulting in a large populace with mixed Spanish and Native American heritage. Historians now write of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century Comanche society as an equestrian empire that shaped the American West.

The broader impacts of this research are many. First, it will produce the first study of Comanche militarism in New Mexico using archaeological evidence that escapes the biases inherent in written documents, which have served as the evidentiary basis for all prior accounts of this key chapter in American history. Second, it will establish the criteria by which Comanche archaeological sites can be distinguished from those of other Plains tribes. Finally, the fieldwork will be undertaken with undergraduate crews from Barnard College, marrying scientific research with training for the next generation of women in archaeology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Following their adoption of an equestrianism lifestyle and their conquest of the rich hunting territories of the Southern Plains, the Comanche emerged as key economic players in the American Southwest as well as a vigorous military force with wide-ranging reach. Eighteenth century Spanish documents acknowledge, in particular, the strong influence of the Comanche on colonial New Mexico, which was largely reliant on Comanche trade even as it was often the target of Comanche raiding. The study of colonial documents, however, provides us with but one perspective on Comanche history—a perspective, moreover, that has been filtered through Spanish colonial priorities and conceptions. How, in contrast, did the Comanche view their own social projects? What were their organizational priorities and conceptions? Alongside the key insights contained within tribal oral histories, this NSF-funded project sprung from a conviction that an archaeological study of eighteenth century sites in northern New Mexico has a great deal of potential to clarify our understanding of Comanche political history.

The project focused on the archaeological remains in the Rio Grande del Norte National Monument, immediately west of the major colonial trade center at Taos Pueblo and centrally located vis-à-vis a number of known areas of Comanche raiding. Prior surveys by the Principle Investigator had revealed that the rift valley at the center of the monument contains not only the remains of colonial-era tipi camps and artifact scatters, but also a dense distribution of scratched and abraded rock art panels that fit broadly within the Plains Biographic Tradition, the latter of which spread up and down the Great Plains alongside the spread of equestrianism. The examples of this rock art tradition in the Rio Grande del Norte National Monument are extraordinary, offering detailed depictions of battles, horse raids, tipi encampments, and many other aspects of Plains life. If these images could be affiliated with the known expansion of Comanche bands into New Mexico during the eighteenth century, then we would suddenly have a rich new archive—produced by the indigenous communities themselves—with which to study Comanche political history. Complicating this possibility, however, is the fact that the Comanche were not the only eighteenth century visitors to the Taos region; Spanish documents clearly point to the frequent presence of ancestral Apache and Ute bands as well, both of whom shared many aspects of Plains material culture with the ancestral Comanche.

This project, then, sought to rigorously test the hypothesized Comanche affiliation of the Plains Biographic rock art in the Rio Grande del Norte National Monument through four research undertakings. First, new portions of the monument were surveyed to significantly expand the existing database of rock art and associated sites. Over the course of four summer field seasons, 1,646 new rock art panels and 48 new sites were located, mapped, and photographed; these included 156 panels within the Plains Biographic tradition. Second, previously located sites with Plains Biographic rock art were revisited to more fully document both the panels and associated artifacts. Third, a regional database was constructed to explore the spatial distributions of not just the Plains Biographic rock art but also other colonial era rock art traditions, as well as the distribution of colonial era artifact scatters. This aspect of the research demonstrated that the scratched and abraded Plains Biographic rock art is not positively correlated with either Apache or Ute artifact assemblages; moreover, it demonstrated that the Plains Biographic rock art is far patchier than other colonial rock art traditions, appearing only in areas of historically documented Comanche movements. Fourth, consultations were conducted with the tribal elders of the Comanche, Jicarilla Apache, and Ute Mountain nations, as well as with members of Taos and Picuris Pueblos. These consultations served the important purpose of sharing the project’s archaeological discoveries with descendant tribal nations, and it also provided an opportunity for tribal knowledge to be incorporated into the interpretation of the rock art. The consultations resulted in the documentation of rich historical information, the most significant of which, for present purposes, was the positive identification of Plains Biographic rock art with specific Comanche signifiers.

The study of the accumulated datasets is ongoing, but the project has already succeeded in establishing a major new historical archive that can now be drawn upon in the study of the Comanche past and in the writing of the broader colonial history of the American Southwest.
